body: Done!
Can you create a new issue please @mattapperson? I don't follow
Green circle = fullscreen. Although, having a shortcut would be cool.

@dariocravero We shouldn't probably expect this since it's not the macOS native behavior – double click changes the size of the window, some apps respect the viewport width as the max, other expand app to the screen edges, but none actually make it go full screen.
By full screen show/hide, do you mean the non native full screen support that was introduced around macos 10.7? if so, i would like the same.
@rauchg I would like to request that this be re-opened to also add support for full screen show/hide as iTerm2 has
@nathanielescribano @rauchg opened here https://github.com/zeit/hyperterm/issues/397
Also, double click on the header should probably do that too
@oskarkrawczyk sorry I meant that behaviour :)
@nathanielescribano do you mean the ctrl-enter shortcut for instant fullscreen, without having to wait for the slow changing screens animation? If so I agree, and haven't seen an issue for this.
@oskarkrawczyk I completely missed the button, since is a _console_ app I expected a shortcut
Good point. I'm going to change that.
Done. Feels much more natural now. Thanks!

I think the same. <kbd>cmd+w</kbd> usually closes the current tab, and one might be afraid to do that while in a webview, since it could cause you to lose the terminal session. <kbd>ctrl+c</kbd> seems suitable, since everybody use that to quit a process.
@Pr0x1m4 I'll add instructions for development. It has to do with installing the native modules with the appropriate flags for electron.
@Pr0x1m4 done! Let me know if those instructions work for you. If so, feel free to close the issue.

Works fine now
![2016-07-02-163941_1920x1080_scrot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4820517/16542587/8b58c104-4074-11e6-85dc-83c4731734f4.png)
I wonder if we should make this the default behavior? Or a default plugin that's enabled built-in?

@leo I shouldn't have downvoted the whole comment – I just think this would be a cool addition, but perhaps a bit too much as the default behavior. It's purely subjective, but I never did like this is Terminal.

I'm 👎 for adding it as a default plugin or feature. I'd much prefer to be able to pick a default directory with something like this plugin I made: [`hyperterm-working-directory`](https://github.com/bevacqua/hyperterm-working-directory).

I'd be more open about a built-in feature like `hyperterm-working-directory`, but with the ability to use the last `cwd` (e.g by setting `workingDirectory` to`'<mirror>'`).

Many users expect a constant default directory, this is something you can do in iTerm 2+, for example
I agree with @leo. In various terminal emulators this is typically a user preference set in config.

If you use tmux, it already has this feature when you create new pane. 
I think default behavior should be $HOME directory as in other terminals.

Or you can have checkbox for tmux-like behavior.

Just to call a few things out here. 

This is line that opens the terminal to $HOME directory:

https://github.com/zeit/hyperterm/blob/master/session.js#L26

I like the idea of making this a plugin, but adding it to the default config plugins.

This follows the pattern that Atom editor set out **solid defaults that you can change**

@rauchg I'm reverse engineering some of the code, and the deeper I dig the more I think I need to provide some hooks into the session before I can write a plugin. Does that seem right to you?

I _think_ the above commit should provide what's needed to solve this. For this to work the plugin would need to update the session's cwd when it changes. Still feel like I'm missing something obvious though.

So I've got this working locally now!

Accepting #174 and adding `hypercwd` to your list of plugins in ~/.hyperterm.js will make this available.

There's a couple things to think about before closing this out.

Do we add a plugin (like [hypercwd](https://github.com/hharnisc/hypercwd) - yes I'm biased 😜) to the default config or leave it to the user to add it.

If we add it by default will it re-add every time HyperTerm gets updated? If it does, probably will want to prevent that from happening.

P.S. The plugin API is awesome!
Also same directory for new window would be great.
@leo Sure, [done](https://github.com/hharnisc/hypercwd/issues/2)!
hypercwd doesn't seem to work on Windows 10.
I'm 👍 for adding it as a feature, not as a default plugin 😅
